questions.neutral: Did you slip in easy tonight?

hobby.message: I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.
Political literature still your guilty pleasure?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Not as smooth tonight—lots of curious eyes.
Just grabbing a drink to clear my head, stranger.
Been busy with personal projects—nothing too thrilling.
Let's just say I enjoy old books and leave it at that.
You'd be surprised how the old words shape our times—if you know where to look.
Took a longer route, more eyes tonight than usual.
Working on some personal research, undiscovered authors, you know.
Just picked up a piece from the lost Republic era. Fascinating stuff.
Been dissecting ideas that feel less timely now, given recent changes.
Halden's death stirred curiosities everywhere—not that it's my concern.
Pretty smooth today, Alex. Familiar faces help.
Got my hands on an intriguing political manuscript recently.
It’s amazing how forgotten texts shed light on current messes.
Been delving into Republic-era literature—compelling insights in old words.
Halden's absence has got me thinking about ideologies buried in dust.
Smooth enough, Alex - not many surprises today.
I find banned literature exciting—been amassing a collection.
Just found an old Republic text that's eerily relevant now.
Fascinated by how our past thinkers frame today's realities.
Halden's sudden exit has me rethinking the stability of our own narratives.
Easy glide tonight—Bartenders are lucky that way, Alex!
I’ve got a passion for banned political literature— it’s my escape.
Recently found a Republic-era manifesto that resonates with current events.
It's intriguing how old ideas challenge our tech-driven governance.
Halden’s demise feels like the echo of beliefs still resonating through time.
, this place feels like a cornerstone of forbidden conversations.
hobby_answer: Well, Alex, times change, but some things remain constant.
Collecting books is a quiet pastime, you know—just appreciating history.
Lot of talk about systems lately, but I prefer printed words.
Halden's passing has everyone on edge, affecting many aspects of life.
Revisiting old texts offers some comfort amidst uncertainty.
New regime, sure, but the old books still have their charm.
I've been collecting since before all the changes, so I have quite a few now.
These days, it's about preserving history, in a sense.
Rare finds are harder to come by since Halden's protocols took hold.
After his death, though, certain texts seem to speak louder than before.
Yes, Alex. New regime, same old books... they're like trusted friends, really.
I delve into them not for rebellion, but for understanding how things evolved.
Interesting how history echoes—especially with Halden's recent departure.
With everything so unpredictable, familiar narratives are stabilizing, in a way.
Despite some hurdles, preserving these narratives feels more vital now.
You guessed it, Alex. The banned books keep me busy. They've somehow gained more weight lately.
With the system changes, these texts offer clarity against a backdrop of constant adaptation.
I find reading them reassuring, like connecting with old thinkers in turbulent times.
Halden's death underscored a reality fracture, making past reflections even more essential.
These works remind me why I started collecting—truths obscured by an ever-shifting present.
Exactly, Alex. The collection's been my anchor as the regime flips through its chapters.
I keep returning to them for context—tools against our meticulously algorithmic present.
Feels like they're speaking to me louder since Halden exited the stage so unexpectedly.
Halden was a system's man, stringent... he left a void, and books fill some of that space.
The contrasts between past texts and our present offer sharp insights into our trajectory.
